mors re ut materiai lucret lib corpus consiciat sed coetum dissipat ollis inde alijs aliud coniungit efficit omnes re vt convertant formas mutentque colores et capiant sensus puncto tempore reddant vt no referre eadem primordium rerum death doth destroy thing matter nought brings onely doth dissolue frame leaues joyning thing changeth shape forme colour rangeth time may know like principle doe flow neither trueth course nature possibly otherwise since intends abolition thing defect contrary owne good succession generation thing roome thereof nature cannot create making something nothing neither annihilate turning something nothing whence consequently followes accesse diminution vniversall alphabet infinite cobination transposition letter waxe alteration seale stamped vpon man take one drop water whole yeare ocean one sand sea shore one grasse earth without new supply nay without supply proportionable additio may fully countervaile repaire subtractio store must continuance time necessity bee emptied vtterly exhausted like manner world finite accesse whole bee perpetuall vniversall decay decrease part thereof pretended must needes last degree annihilated brought nothing reason consent divine incommunicably effect power divine aboue nature worke creation selfe whatsoeuer taken one must necessity giuen another ne re ad nihilum redigantur protinus omnes lest thing ere long nothing brought luc lib put case principall part world still decrease surely others must thereupon continually increase would follow diminution consequently annihilation respect whole vpon continuall decrease others still increase would likewise thereupon follow disproportion jarring could neuer well accord end whole would turned gained losse grew great fall others consequently would proue ruine others themselues splene growing swelling immoderate bignes vpon pining part end ruines selfe due proportion held betwixt part well naturall body man body politique state vpholding whole likewise divine providence vast body world limb member thereof heauens onely excepted remaine without alteration diminution mutually tur e exchange take one another repay one another formerly tooke meanes neither thing lost whole one part either infeebled decrease increase ouer strengthned loose proportion make musicke whole vse seruice whole stand obliged performe purpose surely diuine oracle wisdome trueth thereof poet hath put mouth pythagoras nec specie sua cuique manet rerumque novatrix ovid met ex alijs alias reparat natura figuras nec perit tanto quidquam mihi credite mundo sed variat faciemque novat nascique vocatur incipere esse aliud quam quod fuit ante morique desinere illud idem cum sint huc forsitan illa haec translata illuc summa tamen omnia constant hold long shape soone dame nature one shape lost brings forth another feature beleeue great huge masse nothing doth perish change vary face say thing new borne doth become another wee say thing doth suffer death forme forsakes men signes part time line produce evil bring vpon thing subject vnto necessity diverse sortes inset time vicissitude thing fall motion sea sometime flow prosperity somtime ebbeth back againe evil returne roome thereof dreg matter wee treade vnder foot haue law given vnto breath forth noysome vapour wherewith aire corrupted infect body disable endevours men indeed nearest vnto truth whatsoever seemeth crosse vnto v evill world selfe wee perswading ourselues thing done benefit reason wicked opinion wrongfull accuse event nature plato highest top chiefest piller philosopher maintaineth comentaries fearefull inundation conflagration world purging earth neither wise man affraid call subversion slaughter ruine destruction funeral mankind innovation thing thereby repareing strength recover accrtaine youth agane heaven saith hee raines wee labour know scarcity corne dost thou require element serue thy necessity end thou mayst liue daintily delicately time obsequiously apply themselues thy commodity desireous navigation complaine like sort along time windes blast heaven ceased must wee say fore tranquillitie world pernicious hinders desire passenger hath beene accustomed tosse himselfe sun procure drynesse body like manner complaine pleasure faire cleare weather often cloudinesse taken away must cloudes therefore sayd enimies hang ouerspread skie thou canst thy pleasure frie thy selfe flame prepare occasion drinking event come passe fall vnder cope heaven weighed petty commodity reason order nature itselfe neither thing happen toucheth v affaire vnwelcome success forthwith evill accounted noxious whether worldraine raine raineth ratneth itselfe happily thou knowest either consumes away much moysture fervencie drought temper thes drought long time pouring raines sendeth pestilence disease famine formes evil threatning destruction dost thou know whether take away whichis superfluous itsowne loss set measure riot excesse thing darest thou say evill world originall cause whereof thou art able vnfold resolue happily hinders thy pleasure deleights lustes wilt thou say pernicious cruell cold contrary vnto thy body vse congeale heat thy bloud must winter therefore world thou canst endure fervent heat sun must summer taken yeare nature againe ordered lawes hellebore poison vnto men ought cause bee brought forth wolfe layes wait flocke sheep nature fault hath bred troublesome beast vnto fleecie creature biting serpent taket away life shall therefore speake evill first beginning thing haue added cruell monster vnto living creature arrogant part seeing thy selfe art thine owne livest possession another presume prescribe mightier thy selfe require done thou desirest thou findest ancient constitution already settled thing wherefore men haue complaint take place requisite yee first teach v whence yee whether world made framed ye came stranger vnto country seeing able tell cannot resolue v cause liue vnder hollow vault heaueu leaue suppose thing belongeth vnto seeing thing done alike done reckoned accounted summe intended whole reason christian say evil come god send calamity vpon corne demaund ye say thing doe ye see desperatly open manifest lie ye slander v three hundred yeares lesse since christian began beare name world haue yeares continuall warrs continuall dearth hath peace earth cheapnes plenty thing accuseth v must first demonstrate calamity haue perpetual continuall mortall men haue neuer breathing time without holydayes say haue endured formes manifold danger see middle yeares middle time innumerable victory haue bin obtained conquered enemy territory empire haue bin inlarged nation whose name neuer heard bin brought subiection oftentimes yeares haue yeelded marveilous great increase cheapnes plenty thing buying selling price thing much fallen could thing done could mankind continue vntill time fertility plenty supply whatsoeuer need required sometimes heretofore haue bin need necessity theyhaue bin recompenced abundance war haue bin waged haue afterwards bin corrected victory good successe shall say thegods somtime mindfull misery somtime againe vnmindfull time famine said angry followeth time plenty aengry displeased brought issue turnes lightly lay aside take vp anger remembrance offence returne afresh vnto although wbieh say seemes inexplicable cannot knowne vnderstood therefore would haue almans persian scythian subdued christian dwell liue among nation giue roman victory seeing christian dwelt liued among nation also pleasure mouse locust therefore swarme asia syria like manner christian dwelt nation time swarme spaine france seeing innumerable christian liued province also cause send drought vpon corne barrennesse among getulians aquitaine yeare giue plentifull harvest moore numidian like religion setled country also one citty haue caused hatred name many perish famine place haue dearenes provision made body even true christian also much richer wealthier behoued therefore either none haue thing comfortable cause euils nation seeing yee see thing profitable mingled incommodious leaue length ascribe vnto v impeacheth estate since hindrance wealth prosperity uestimentum sayth hee quod sumitur ad vsum cessante vsu deponitur heaven shall wax old doth garment vse shall cease together man doth vse garment vseth exposition hee seemes haue borrowed dydimus functae munerihus suis abibunt psalmist professeth shall waxe old changed meaning shall vse garment hauing performed vse ordained folded vp layd aside heaven earth finished service created shall vanish passe away vpon comment dydimus eugubinus thus commeth hoc autem lib de perenni philosophia summus docet theologus primum mundum antiquandum vetustate senio interiutrum sed noneo senio quo re mortales corrumpuntur atque abolentur coelo tale senium nullum est sed alium quoddam cujus similitudo ex vestibus ostenditur cum deponimus ea vbi nobis esse vsui desijssent tanquam invtiles ea exuimus atque obuoluimus sic mundus id est coelum non eo delebitur quod eadem vetustate atque omnia animalia arbores aliquando sit defecturus sed quia cessabit vsus ejus quo rerum tantos ordines peragebat purpose greate divine teach heaven wax old consume age old age thing mortall suffer corruption dissolusion heaven waxing old found another kind resemblance whereof taken garment put hauing vse laying aside folding vp like manner heaven shall therefore disolued shall time suffer defect thorow old age beastes plantes feele vse shall cease kept inferiour body due order perchance apostle himselfe rendring word psalmist intends much vesture shalt thou fold vp curtaines carpet hanging folded heb vp layd aside family remoues seemes likewise haue foretold prophet isayah heaven shall rouled together scrole shall passe away noyce sayth peter like hissing parchment riueled vp heat signifies originall pet word place howsoever shall wax old course nature mightie power god nature created shall dissolue nothing else prophet seemes point passage tu mutabis mutabuntur thou shalt change nature thou shalt change shall changed fresh lustre brightnesse wherwith commonly thought heauens shall renewed last day garment turning changed changing refreshed may well making resplendent euer time since first creation scowring contracted rust adding new glosse augmentation glory whereas divine haue doubted make spot shadowes appearing face moone vndoubted argument contracted rust spot beene originall natiue equall date moone selfe beene contracted age continuance time wrinkle beautifull face haue beene late cleerely distinctly discerned former age prooues sydera medcaea lately discouered vertue instrument discoverer themselues knew well enough could colour reason affirme galilaeus ought finde obserued mathematician time rather thinke haue beene blazing light created region aire carrying resemblance starre new true created starre seated firmament appeared cassiopaea yeare one moone beeing ignorant eccles motion thereof thou werst christian beginnest sacrilegious sacrilege thou committest thy creator thou imputest impotency creature thou changest like moone thou shinedst devotion faith fallest away thorow weakenes vnbeleefe thou changest like moone thy braine voide wit moone light could wish thou diddest indeed change moone shee quickely returnes againe fulnes thou leasure vse thy wit shee soone recovers light thou slowly faith thou hast denyed thy change worse moone shee suffers eclipse light thou thy soules health willsome man say moone labour yes indeed shee two notable conclusion one lib instit cap starres god gentile commonly imagined governed god epicurians denyed former saith argumentum illud quo colligunt vniversa coelestia deos esse contrarium valet atque illuc passim sine vlla necessitate ferrentur sicut animantes terra quorum quia liberae sunt voluntates huc atque illuc vagantur vt libet quocunque men duxerit eo feruntur argument whence heathen doe collect starres must needes god doth plainly prooue contrary take god certainty course therein much deceiued plainely prooveth indeed god able depart set course whereas god would mooue way way firmenes stablenes heaven vnchangeable law hath wheeled many thousand yeares yet wasted worne motion thereof established god againe within hee vseth almost wordes firmamentum non dicitur de duritie aut soliditate impermeabili sed de firmitate qua perpetuo motu circumactum coelum non atteritur nec absumitur sed manet quale deo initio fuit firmatum nay little last passage diuiding whole firmament wherevnto may adde noted starres many number namely one thousand twenty two besides planet magnitude greate every one appeare fixed firmament sayd bee much bigger least time time whole globe water earth sunne againe much exceede globe biggest may iustly bee stiled sonne syrach instrumentum admirabile wonderfull instrument fyre would doubtlesse long ecclesiastcus ere haue turned world ash infinite disproportion betweene flame little quantity matter supposed bee prepared fewell therefore bee fed vapour aristotle deservedly laugh childish ridiculous device much vapour ascend higher middle region ayre thence distill againe vpon water earth whence drawne vp vapour vncertaine flame likewise feeding vpon must needes vncertaine dayly vary themselues quantity figure according proportion fewell sect heate breed springes light consequently light decayed neither warmth arising absurdity opinion beeing foule grosse remaines sunne starres infuse warmth subcaelestiall body hot themlselues beeing ordeined god breed heate matter capable thereof impart life creature yet themselues remaine voyd life like braine imparts sense every member body yet selfe vtterly voyd sense againe attribute effect motion others light glorious body true indeed motion cause heat attenuation rarefaction ayre reason moone neerer earth warme sunne many thousand mile farther distant higher region aire alway hotter lower notwithstanding wee compare second lowest vndoubtedly false moreouer motion coelestiall body vniforme heat deriued reason likewise motion ceasing heat likewise cease yet shall neuer beleeue sun stood still prayer iosua ceased warme inferiour body find experience sun work powerfully vpon body stand still moue reason seemes rest motion body warming warmed receiueth imparteth midsomer day againe two yeares moneths iuly august continued fervently hot men rosted egges sand least wee think immoderate cold answerable heate go tels v reigne lewis son charlemaigne yeare eight hundred twenty one winter long sharpe small brooke streames rheine danubius albis seene generally great river france germany hard frozen space thirty dayes loaden cart passed beene vpon bridge vndaque jam tergo ferratos sustinet orbes virgill georgicks puppibus illa prius patulis nunc hospita plaustris river backe iron wheeles sustaines ship ere wagon entertaines yeare one thousand eighty six winter continued bitter martyns day eleventh november first aprill rheine passible foote vnseasonable cold regard time yeare hee report hermannus contractus yeare one thousand sixty three midst aprill space fower dayes weather cruell raging windes abundance snow kild cattle bird destroyed vine tree lastly vouches robertus de monte yeare one thousand one hundred twenty fiue sore byting winter innumerable eeles reason long continuance ice came creeping ditch hiding themselues meddowes found dead rotten wonderfull excesse cold vpon tree scarce appeared leaues till moneth may conclusion quorsum ego ista vt opinio illa novitatis eximatur quae male omni dolore aut querela blanditur nunquam tale nemini tantum nugae et plebeii sermones quos historiae refutent serio lectae hunc quoque constantiae fructum animo gignant end example alleadged surely purpose worke men mindes opinion novelty strangenesse wherewith vsually flatter selues griefe complaintes never like age ever saw felt measure trifling speech beseeming vulgar confuted history accuratly read may serue arme v constancy like accident thinke wee shall hardly reade heare sharper frost latter age ovid mention place whither hee banished beeing nudaque consistunt formam servantia testa vina nec hausta meri sed data frustum bibunt ovid de trist bare wine still keeping forme caske stand fast gulpes gobbet wine tast agreeable wherevnto virgill caedunt que securibus humida vina georgick liquid wine ax doe cleaue serres life francis first report siege luxenbuge yeare weather cold provant wine ordained armie frozen divided hatch souldiers carried away basket tacitus speaking annal romanes warre armenia tell v winter sharpe earth long couered yce could pitch tent vnlesse first digged ground many limmes grew starke extremitie cold many died keeping watch souldier noted carrying fagot whose hand stiffe frozen sticking burthen fell though beene cut armes sect excessiue draugh cold raine former age heere home com mon complaint vnseasonable weather age together reason thereof wee looke neerer home wee shall find yeare one thousand one hundred fourteene fourteenth yeare king henry first riuer thames dryed vp survey london ex l bermun want water betweene tower london bridge vnder bridge selfe onely horse great number men woman child daily wade ouer foote excessiue vnseasonable frost raine snow haile windes like story full specially stowe chronicle many immoderate wee haue none latter time comparable therevnto true indeede generall ilands beeleeue aboue world subject vncertainety weather many time wee hardly distinguish christmas midsummer onely length day warme christmas againe stormy cold midsummer raine thorow yeare thinke wee haue vpon continent may justly call iland matulam planetarum vrinall planet giue one instance two twentieth yeare edward third midsummer christmasse part hollenshed continually raind one day night dry together take bee specially environed sea withall stand farre northwest since still situate likely aire heere part tempered distempered former age yet know complaint common summer reason cold moist kindely haue beene sternuntur segetes deplorata colonis votajacent longique perit labor irritus anni corne lie plowman doth complaine hope voide toiling yeare hee onely hath labour paine neither altogether deny may bee god hath quarrell v sinnes seekes chastisement draw v neerer himselfe vniversall decay nature doubtlesse complaint hath still beene time father grandfather great grandfather vpward regard generation nonne quotidie hoc murmuratis hoc dicitis quam augustinus psal illa verba quis est homo qui vult vitam diligit di videre b no diu ista patimur quotidie peiora peiora apud parentes nostros fuerunt dy laetiores fuerunt dy meliores si interrogares ipsos parentes tuos similiter tibi de diebus suis murmurarent fuerunt beati patres nostri no miseri sumus malos dy habemus doe daily murmurre thus say long shall wee suffer thing thing grow worse worse father saw better merrier dayes wish thou wouldst aske question thy father thou shalt finde murmurre likewise regard day saying oh father happy wee miserable wee see domus defossi iu altum specus remedia sunt ignis ille coelestis non transverberat terram sed exiguo ejus objectu retunditur pestilentia mutare sedes licet nullum malum sine effugio est nunquam fulmina populos percusserunt pestilens coelum exhausit vrbes non abstulit hoc malum latissime patet inevitabile avidum publice noxium non enim domus solum familias aut vrbes singulas haurit sed gens totas reason thereof strength better supporting navigable vessells still sea mother water likewise river daughter thereof ither hold wonted course current haue diminished one age place haue againe recompenced repayed another sr bo hath well expressed sea river lib quoniam omnia moventur transmutantur aliter talia ac tanta administrari non possent existimandum est nec terram ita semper permanere vt semper tanta sit nec quicquam sibi addatur aut adimatur sed nec aquam nec candem sedem semper ab istis obtineri presertim cum transmutatio ejus cognata sit ac naruralis quini terrae multum aquam convertitur aqua multum terram transmutatur quare minime mirandum est si ea terrae partes quae nunc habitantur olim mare occupabat quae pelagus sunt prius habitabantur quemadmodum de fontibus alios deficere contingit alios relaxari item flumina lacus thnigs moue changed without great matter could well disposed thinke earth doth remaine alwayes state without addition diminution neither yet water alwayes bounded within list specially seeing mutuall chang naturall kindly rather much earth turned water cotrarywise lesse water earth wondered part earth habitable formerly overflowed water againe sea sometimes habitable among fountaines dried vp spring forth afresh may also verified river lake wherewith accordes poet vidi ego quod fuerat quondam solidissima tellus esse fretum vidi factas ex aequore terras et procul pelago chonchae jacuere marinae metamorp et vetus inventa est montibus anchora summis quodque fuit campus vallem decursus aquarum fecit eluvie mon est deductus aequor eque paludosa siccis humus aret arenis quaeque sitim tulerant stagnata paludibus hument hic fontes natura nouos emisit et illic clausit antiquis tam multa tremoribus orbis flumina prosiliunt aut exsiccata residunt firme land sometimes haue seen made sea sea made land againe mountaine top old anchours found haue sea fish shell lie farre maine plaines turne vale water fall downe overflowes changd champaine land dry ground erewhile moorish fen doth drowne fen againe turnd thirsty sand fountaines new hath nature opened shut vp spring earst flow amaine earthquake river oft haue issued dryed vp haue sunke downe againe poet bringes instance like purpose pontanus sed nec perpetuae sedes sunt fontibus vllae lib mete aeterni aut manant cursus mutantur aeuum singula inceptum alternat natura tenorem quodque dy antiqua tulit post auferet ipsa fountaines spring eternally one place perpetually tary thing every age evermore vary nature changeth still course begun herselfe vndoe old hath done though true many yet great one indus ganges danubius rhene nilus little nothing varied course current held thousand yeares since appeares description ancient geographer aboue meethinkes constant rising nilus continued many age one greatest wonder world precise regard time take earth adjoyning river preserue carefully come neither wet wasted weigh dayly shall finde neither lesse heavy till seventeenth iune day begineth groweth reported mr ge sand common experiment affirmed alpinus phisitia marchitus french consull elianus iesuite varrat englishma ponderous augmenteth augmentation river fish inhabitant thereof leastwise regard number much decayed wee may take vp poet omne peractum est iuvenal sat et iam defecit nostrum mare sea length spent faile sea growne fruitlesse barren pretended regard former age appeares vpon record hauen townes thing neither affirme deny hauing searched selfe themselues make objection shape sufficient answere therevnto telling v may extraordinary judgment god dealt egyptian death fish abuse fleshpots intrusion hollander carry coast store might much better loade selues little enlarge view cast eye abroad comparing one part world another shall easily discerne though coast faile abundance formerly ouerlaying yet others still abound plentifull manner experience found vpon coast virginia present doubt coast spared space yeares would againe afford great plenty euer finally store fish decay reason decay world must necessity follow likewise store plant beast bird men dayly decay vertue reason nay rather since curse lighting vpon man extended plant beast fish thing finde expressely registred holy scripture neither vniversall deluge hurt rather helpe rest perished still doubt euen day first creation sea found many fish many feature bartas water one may see creature found world within deepes drownd store fish way diminished neither decayed either greatnes goodnes instance whale king fish iob termes king ouer child pride basil seeke honour dignity heere exercise rule authority wee covet wealth rich mankind set vpon stir trouble raise civill warres still one another mutuall massacre murthers make roome therein let passe publique furie nation abroad wherein wee chace driue neighbour borderer stealth dig turfth neighbour soyle put owne man hath extended land gotten whole countreyes himselfe farre neere goodly deale earth enjoyeth say set bound full measure covetous desire great portion thereof shall hold dead head layed thus pliny seneca sweetly accord hoc est punctum quod inter tot gens ferro igne dividitur oquam ridiculi sunt mortalium terminus nat quaest l praef punctum certe est illud quo navigamus quo bellamus quo regna disponimus point many nation share fire sword oh ridiculous bound mortall men verily point inwhich saile wage warres dispose kingdomes sublime speculation wee descend examination earth supposed decay aelian eight booke history telleth v onely cap mountaine aetna thereof might thing grow dust earth diminution mountaines blaucanus obserues caused partly rainewater partly riuers continuall fretting little little wash away eate top side feete mountaines whence part thus fretted continuall falling downe weare mountaines fill vp lower place valleyes making one increase decrease whence come passe old house heretofore fairely built almost buried vnder ground windowes heretofore set reasonable height growen euen pauement write triumphall arch septimius foote capitol mountaine rome almost couered earth somuch inforced descend downe many staires formerly vsed ascend whereas contrariwise romane capitoll selfe seated mountaine hanges ouer witnesseth george agricola discouers foundation plainely aboue ground without question first laying thereof deepe rooted earth whereby apppeares mountaine looseth valley gaines consequently whole globe earth nothing lost onely remoued one place another processe time highest mountaines may humbled valleyes againe lowest valleyes exalted mountaines ought nought fall felt seene within still loosing somewhat selfe length would come nothing death fatall strength could altogether substance destroy thing vanish euen soone die bartas time mighty mountaines top bated fall neighbour vale fatted trent avon overflow reaue one field next bestow whereas another poet tels v eluviemons est diductus aequor mountaine washing oft ovid met sea brought certaine experience found true river daily carrie much earth sea sea sends backe againe much slime sand earth place namely north part deuonshire found bee marveilous great commoditie inriching soyle earth nothing diminished regard dimension measure thereof surface center first creation neither fatnes fruitfulnes thereof leastwise since flood regard duration alone whit impaired though haue yeelded store increase space many reuolutions age yet hee made continually reneweth face thereof psalmist speakes turning thing spring againe saith one cuncta suos ortus repetunt matremque requirunt another e terris orta terra rursus accipit third joynes together quapropter merito maternum nomen adepta est cedit enim retro de terra quod fuit ante lucr l terras altogether may thus vnfitly rendred thing returne originall seeke mother earth doth spring againe earth doth fall neither doe heerein dissent syracides manner liuing thing hath hee couered face earth shall returne againe doome passed vpon first man fall ingraven forehead onely posterity earthly creature made sake dust thou art vnto dust shalt thou returne ocean mainetained returne river drayned deriued earth dissolution reuersion body receiue growth nourishment grasse feede beast corne strengthen wine cheere heart man either might bee regard earth heauens good plentifull euer decree almighty like law medes persian irreuocable shall bee signes season dayes yeares againe heereafter seed time harvest cold heat gen summer winter day night shall cease long earth remaineth certainety reuolutions se sua per vestigia voluitur annus virgill yeare owne step selfe returnes could well storke turtle crane swallow fowles obserue precisely doe ier appointed time comming going whereas commonly thought beleeued time yeare vnseasonable heeretofore thereby fruites earth neither faire kindely haue beene first answere complaint hath beene euer since salomon time hee observeth winde shall sow regardeth clowdes eccles shall reape seemes weather euen vncertaine likewise vncertaine vnkindely riping fruites may appeare word following place morning sow thy seede euening let thy hand rest v thou knowest whether shall prosper whether shall bee alike good sometimes wee haue vnseasonable yeares reason excessiue wet cold againe paid home immoderate drought heate v yet neighbour country v thinke man bee vnwise partiall affirme constant perpetuall declination vnseasonablenes yeares recompensed seasonablenes others true erroneous computation yeare wee vse may cause seeming alteration season thereof neither man else thinke euer yet obserued continuance time theirveines wasted impaired one treatise hath expresly composed de veteribus novis metallis wherein shewes old exhausted new discouered true indeede lib proaem pliny hath observed wee descend entrailes earth wee goe downe farre seat habitation infernall spirit meete rich treasure shee fruitfull enough beneficiall vnto v vpper face thereof shee permitteth v walke tread vpon yet notwithstanding couetousnesse toyle men mine neuer drawn dry store emptied earth onely backe doth beare abundant treasure gliftring every inwardly shees lesse fraught rich nay rather foules bewitches bartas day weeke within deepe fold fruitfull lappe boundlesse mine treasure doth shee wrappe th hungry hand humane avarice cannot exhaust labour device starres consequently eclypses tract time must needes increase number thing depending vpon planet decay degenerate vertues operation former opinion already proued certainely false latter altogether vncertaine effect eclypses produce cannot punctually define strange accident graunt aswell course nature ciuill affaire haue often followed vpon appeares cyprianus leouicius hath purposely composed tract mr camden obserues towne shrewesbery suffered twice grievous losse fire within compasse fiftie yeares vpon two severall eclypses sunne aries whether accident ascribed precedent eclypses cannot certainely affirme wee sure moone eclypsed interposition earth sun moone since night nothing else interposition earth betweene v sunne see reason wee daily feare dangerous effect every night thicke cloud eclypse verily beleeue ground errour also former sprang fro ignorance cause eclypses sulpitius gallus first amongst romanes amongst greekes thales milesius finding nature prognosticate forshew hipparchus compiled ephimerides containing course aspect planet six hundred yeares ensuing lesse assuredly hee beene privy nature counsailes great person excellent doubtles saith pliny aboue reach humane thinke deny repairable tract revolution time irrepairable yet decay creature ariseth deficiencie themselues waxing old removall first original poynt question adventitious externall cause passe creature consideration man commaunder compendium rest whose sake first made discourse first vndertaken lib iii pretended decay mankind regard age duration strength stature art witts cap touching pretended decay men regard age first way comparison betweene age ancient latter time sect short life man regard duration many creature created mortall falne haue beene preserued immortality since vpon exammination wee haue found perpetuall vniversall decay pretended hea en earth ayre water fish plant beastes mineralls see reason thence wee might safely sufficiently conclude neither decay man discourse principally vndertaken intended sake mankind consider compare former age latter first regard age secondly regard strength stature thirdly regard wit invention fourthly lastly regard manner condition vpon due consideration comparison shall appeare decay supposed question trust touchthe world decay generall soone end ordinary age man compared heaven stone mettalls beast tree short longest copared god eternity span shadow dreame shadow nay meere nothing romane oratour hath truly observed eligantly expressed apud hypanim fluuium qui ab europae psal tusculan parte pontum influit aristoteles ait bestiolas quasdam nasci quae vnum diem viuant ex ijs igitur hora octaua quae mortua est provecta aetate mortua est quae vero occidente sole decrepita eo magi si etiam solstitiali die confer nostram longissimam aetatem cum aeternitate eadem propemodum brevitate qua istae bestiolae reperiemur aristole writes river hypanis side europe fals pontus certaine little animal bred liue day amongst dye eight houre dy old dye sun set dye decrepit age specially vpon day sumer solstice copare age eternity shall found regard duration almost state shortnesse creature body man even fall doubtlesse selfe reaof contrary element contrary humour member contrary temper whereof composed dissoluble morrall also reason outward accident dayly wasting natiue heate disproportionable supply radicall moisture defect creator supplyed arming outward accident divine providence guard angel owne excellent wisedome contrariety fighting body harmony soule wasting natiue heat radicall moysture supernaturall vertue efficacy gaue fruit tree life naturally mortall otherwise even fall haue continued immortall apostate angells speciall priviledge dispensation immortall mortalis erat saith augustine lib de gen ad lit c conditione corporis animalis immortalis autem beneficioconditoris mortall respect naturall body immortall favour creator yet doubtles sinned still liued vpon earth though likelihood age might extended thousand yeares haue beene length translated hence heaven could neither haue sinned dyed sic est immortalis conditus sayth gregory vt tamen si peccaret mori moral lib cap possit sic mortalis est conditus vt si non peccaret etiam non mori possit atque ex merito liberi arbitrij beatitudinem illius regionis attingeret qua vel peccare vel mori non possit created immortall sinned might dye againe created mortall could dye merit freewill haue beene translated place blisse could neither sinne dye sect long liues patriarch manner computing yeares almighty god drew line liues length reason proper first time though vpon fall man duration continuance vpon earth much shortned yet certaine many ancient patriarch floud liued aboue nine hundred allmost thousand yeares neither ought seeme incredible though plyny mentioning reported haue liued fiue sixe eight hundred yeares length concludes lib cap strange report arise ignorance time past want knowledg made account saith reckoned summer one yeare winter another also reckoned every quarter yeare arcadian whose yeare three moneths againe haue namely egyptian count every chaunge new moone yeare therefore marvell gyants hughest monstrous gyant euer world beheld vpon ground seemes though faisely supposed iohannes lucidus lib de emendatione temporum cap v vit labour proue indeede passage fourteenth iosua latter time haue also afforded like home abroad specially indie liue according nature like may said succeeding age downe present time confession cassanion booke gyants vno tantum seculo aut altero visi sunt sed ferme ab initio mundi ad davidis vsque tempora propagatum id genus hominum magnitudine prorsus admiranda haue beene seene one onely two age almost beginning world euen david time hath kinde men monstrous bignesse beene deduced augustine go farther quasi vero corpus hominum modum nostrum longe excedentia de civit dei non etiam nostris temporibus nata sint body men much exceeding ordinary stature likewise borne time yet fully ninth chapter booke nunquam ferme defuerunt qui modum aliorum plurimum excederint haue almost time beene wanting haue much exceeded ordinary stature insist onely vpon signall instance drawne testimony approved authours gospells writing apostle wee reade intending matter greater weight consequence pliny tell v reigne claudius emperour mighty man one gabbara name lib c brought arabia roome nine foote hith many inch likewise time augustus caesar two others named pusio secondilla higher gabbara halfe foote whose body preserved kept wonder within salustian garden maximinus emperour iulius capitolinus affirmes exceeded eight foote andronichus comninus tenne nicetas dayes theodosius one syria nicephorus report fiue cubit high handbreadth himselfe seene latter time hath beene written strongly auerred body william conquerour found vncorrupt foure hundred hollenshed vol lib c yeares buried length eight foote former could well since tombe narrow vnbowelled body say story brake laying downe latter litle shew since haue written life agree man meane middle stature though limmes actiue strong full confutation said fable saith stow restlesse bone hardly obtained intombing toward latter end life afterwards vnluckily againe lose yeare christ viz chastillion conducting remnant escaped battell dreux tooke citie cane certaine sauage souldiers aswell english others beat downe vtterly deface noble monument victorious king pulling bone spitefully threw away could finde treasure falsely surmised beene laid vp others specially english snatched euery one haue peece making wonder would haue done exceeded length bignesse men bone latter yeares whereas indeede thing noted haue beene certainely informed saith authour english men good credit present eyewitness spoyle monument bone brought part realme theuet likewise second tome cosmographie describing city cane mentioneth rifling monument monstrous lib cap bone body found hee ordinary stature mankind remaine notwithstanding incredulous diffident peremptory daring case becanus non credam illud orionis apud plynium licet lucius flaccus metellus qui visum iuisse dicuntur per decrementa sint vnles homer thought men anciently bigger taller world waxed old decrease thing men nisi si gellius weake thereby draw side specially considering said immediatly varro testimony prevailes somuch peter martyr hee lo orum com c clas cannot yeeld decrease since floud si rogarer sayth existimem corpus humana quae postea fuerunt ab ijs immin ta esse quae ante diluvium producebantur fortassis annuerem sed quod diluvio vsque ad hanc nostram aetatem perpetuo decrescant id non facile concederem verbis praesertim annotatis quae aulos gellius libr scripsit vbi ait modum adolescendi humani corporis esse septem pedum quae mensura hodie quo que videtur esse staturae procerioris apocryphis tamen esdrae legimus lib ad finem cap ne quid dissimulem nunc minora esse corpus nostra ac indie imminuenda quod natura semper magi effoeta reddatur idem que vt paulo ante dixi cyprianus videtur statuere sed quare tam facile assentiar causam attuli quia de mensura quam gellius definivit hodie nihil propemodum videam immutatum demaunded whether thinke men body since floud decreased regard floud happily grant since floud downward present age still decrease would easily yeeld specially observing word aulus gellius hath third booke hee sayth measure growth man body seaven foote day seemes heigth tallest stature yet conceale nothing wee read indeede fourth booke toward end fifth chapter apocryphall esdras body lesse still shall lessened asmuch nature euery day weakened opinion said seemes approved cyprian cannot easily yeeld assent therevnto haue giuen reason find litle capable reply eos qui sic arbitrantur insigniter falli contendo ferunt enim corpus aeque nunc helleborum atque olim eodem vel majori pondere vt ipse alijs meipso sum expertus verum inscitia eorum qui nihil medici habent praeter titulum vestem longam impudentem arrogantiam causa est vt sic opinentur confident thus thinke notablely deceiued asmuch body aswell endure like greater quantity elleborum daunger good successe administred body though inferiour strength roger bacon booke de erroribus medicorum tell v disposition heaven changed euery centenary thereabout consequently thing growing earth change complexion also doth body man therevpon infers eaedem proportiones medicinarum non sunt semper continuandae sed exigitur observantia certa secundum temporis discensum proportion medicine still continued required certain quantity according variation time change disposition heaven cannot conceiue intends alwayes worst crosse himselfe booke neither thing know haue certainty change speakes sure haue met fully opened seriously vrged archangelus piccolhomini anatomicall lecture wil expresse word speaking first gut thus go dicitur etiam graecis dodecadactylos nobis duodenu lib lect quod duodecem digitos longum illis temporibus videretur nam nostris temporibus vix digitorum apex aequat fortassequod hac nostra aetate homines minores illis saeculis grandiores essent idcirco longiora mebra proportione respondetia dicitur quo que pyloros id est ianitor portonarius translato nomine inferioris orificij ventriculus ad superiorem duodeni partem quae ex eo proxime enascitur called graecians dodecadactylos v duodenum seemes time haue beene inch long whereas age hardly equal toppes nine finger perchance adayes men lesse bigger likewise bigger part body answereable therevnto also called pyloros porter name borrowed nether orifice stomacke applyed higher part duodenum growes thus meanes apex toppes nine finger doe well apprehend riolanus sure booke chapter anthropographia tell v plainely ab herophylo duodenum dicitur quoniam olim duodecem transversos digitos longum erat vbi hodie vix quatuor digitos aequat herophylus called duodenum anciently inch long whereas scarce full foure long since herophilus liued cannot certainely determine well coniecture name finde gesner bibliotheca indeed tertullian booke de anima mentioneth appeares liued long appeares suppose bee hundred yeares much reason well bee demanded vpon supposition allow haue liued two thousand yeares agoe granted withall part man body decayed proportionably duodenum piccolomini himselfe confesseth thereof thinke wise learned man offer make doubt say granted must necessitie follow space yeares two third humane stature lost proportio men fiue foote high yeares againe shall allow like proportion decrease like space time foot high vpward vnreasonable affirme conceiue leaue author patron fancie imagine againe would willingly knowe whether herophilus time inch belike notorious diminution stature collected varied according diminution stature duodenum aswell inch duodenum inch say inch inch irregular coparison matter altogether incredible wonder galen hippocrates ancient physitians found variation thereof time regard former age aswell wee regard finding haue left record mention notable observation writing think strong presumption indeed either practise reading observed matter make plaine full answere objection need go farther riolanus immediatly annexed passage alleadged nec mensuram antiquam deprehendes nisi graciliorem angustiorem ventriculus partem fundo inferne exporrectam vsque ad anfractuum principium addideris quam saepe digitos aequare vidi neither shall finde ancient measure vnlesse adde duodenum lower narrower part stomack extend place gut begin pleat winding haue often seene equall inch word make mine answere thus take duodenum strictly onely much lowest orifice stomacke winding gut say scantly foure inch long take thinner part end ventricle greekes call pyloros latines thence ianitor portonarius porter riolans observation hath doubt may found fully long ancient measure pyloros hath beene ancient writer taken duodenum accounted one onely riolan place alleadged laurentius lib cap piccolhomini himselfe confesseth latter part passage already quoted leonardus fuchsius third booke chapter paradox brings purpose celsus lib cap avicen fen tract cap valescus iohannes matthaeus de gradi commentary vpon ninth booke razis cap lastly alexander benedictus second booke anatomie chapt though make galen speake different language yet riolan others another opinion therein while part even vpon going presse came mine hand two bookes written two learned french men iacobus capellus iohannes temporarius one intituled de mensuris chronologicae demonstrationes bellarmine cannot speake ninth age patience seculo hoc nullum extitit de romane pontifice l c indoctius aut infoelicius quo qui mathematicae aut philosophiae operam dabat vulgo magus putabatur neuer age vnlearned vnhappy studied mathematikes philosophy commonly held magician sabellicus stand admiring palpable egyptian darkenesse thereof mirum est quantum eneead omnium bonarum artium obliuio per id tempus mortalium animos obrepserit vt ne pontificibus quidem vllis siue principibus quicquam illuceret quod vitam iuvare possit wonder strange forgetfullnes good art time crept vpon mindes men neither prelate prince appeared thing might farther ciuilitie genebrard sort blesseth himselfe infoelix dicitur hoc seculum chron lib exhaustum hominibus doctrina ingenio claris sine etiam claris principibus atque pontificibus called vnhappie age void men renowned either wit learning also without famous either prince prelate great alteration study endeavour men diverse age sometimes better sometimes worse god blessing better againe sect lawyer last age preferred former time next god lawes empire seeme challenge place howbeit v hauing neither reward imployment deserue haue lost ranke dignitie forraine part cherished honoured maruellously flourish somuch transmarine kingdomes lawyer held part vndoubtedly sufficient schollers diuines within last centenarie much sufficient writer professours facultie many precedent age aswell part professed schooles practique expressed judgement pleading shall judiciously compare baldus bartolus iason accursius cuijacius alciatus ottomannus duarenus french men shall easily finde latter phrase polite methode exact marrow true sence law profound instance onely two first cuijacius memorable testimonie yeelded massonius iacobus cuijacius juris romani radix tanta cura effossas lucem protulit vt caeteri ante eum ignorasse illas ipse solus post multos quaesiuisse diligentius penitius invenisse videatur iames cujace great industry digged vp brought light rootes imperiall law others seemed ignorant alone others haue sought diligently discouered fully pithaeus outuies massonius epitaph erected doubt stile romani iuris primis conditoribus interpretem primum vltimum first last interpreter romane law since first founder thereof adding withall cleere natiue light soeuer brought science present age hath deriued posterity must judgement one terence comedy pla declined martiall iuvenall silius statius grew old serenus sidonius severinus ausonius sprang vp reflourished againe palingenius aonius politianus cerratus vida pontanus sanazarus fracastorius quos cum quovis veterum compare multis non ignobilibus anteponas saith scaliger man may safely compare ancient preferre many lowest ranke crinitus censure latin poet differs much scaligers famianus strada hath libris de poetis latinis well censured imitated chiefe hee come nothing short author themselues bee wondred therein act different part apply different vaines nay imitation claudian expressing controversie lutist nightingale quicknes life may without prejudice equalled thing antiquity boast kinde true mantuan excepted monkes fryars counted onely schollers excelled poetry part delighted rhyming without either sharpnesse wit neatnesse stile sometimes wanted three witnesse poore verse vpon venerable bede presbyter hic beda requiescit carne sepultus dona christe animam coelis gaudere per aevum daque illi sophiae debriari fonte cui jam suspiravit ovans intentus semper amore presbyter bede corse rest buried graue grant christ soule heauen eternall joyes may haue giue drunke well wisedome joy loue striud breathed verse william malmesburie though himselfe monke bitterly de rebus gestis anglorum l censure shamefull one vnworthy monument worthy man neither shame saith lessned kinde excuse monasterie while liued flourished schoole good letter man could found commend memory posterity barren slender stile yet tollerable verse regard passed applause succeeding age famous king ethelbert epitaph set vpon rex ethelbertus hic clauditur poliandro fana pians certus christo meat absque meandro king ethelbert lyeth closd polyander building church sure go christ without maeander gervasius de blois son king stephen abbot westminster buried de regum genere pater hic gervasius ecce est defunctus mors rapit omne genus even father gervase borne king race loe dead thus death sort doth deface vpon great seale edward confessor verse ing en sigillum eaduuardi anglorum basilei pity mishap francis petrarch man singular learning himselfe excellent poet time afforded bone could finde better epitaph arqua italy frigida francisci lapis hic tegit os petrarchae suscipe virgo parens animam sate virg ne parce fessa que jam terris coeli requiesc stone doth couer cold bone anc petrarch thou virgin mother take soule thou christ pardon grant weary earth rest heauens arke together regeneration kindes learning poetrie likewise grew request among infinite number excelled kinde onely instance two ronsard buchanan former pasquier hath written singular epigram seu tibi numeri maroniani lib seu placent veneres catulli sive tu lepidum velis petrarcham siue pindaricos modos referre ronsardus numeros maronianos ronsardus veneres catullianas neonon italicum refert petrarcham neonon pindari um refert leporem quin tam bene pinda mulatur quin tam varie expr mit petrarcham atque virgilium meum catullum hunc ipsum vt magi aemulentur illi rursus tam graviter refert maronem vt nullus putet hunc catullianum rursus tam lepide refert catullum vt nullus putet hunc maronianum et cum sit maro totus catullus totus pindarus petrarcha totus ronsardus tamen est sibi perennis quod si nunc redivivus extet vnus catullus maro pindarus petrarcha et quotquot veteres fuere vates ronsardum nequeant simul referre vnus qui reliquos refert poetas whether thee maros number please elegant catullus vaine petrarch thuscan gracefulnesse theban pindar lofty straine ronsard doth maros rime expresse elegant catullus vaine petrarch thuscan gracefulnesse theban pindar lofty straine expresseth pindar stile doth catullus emulate virgil petrarch seeme imitate graue maro resembles none would thinke catullian elegant catullus none would thinke maronian though catullus virgill pindar petrarch yet ronsard still maro catullus might see pindar petrarch liue againe thold poet lesse joyntly hit ronsards vaine onely doth expresse may adde pithaeus epitaph vpon ronsard summe poetarum quos prisca nostra tulerunt quos que ferent galli posthuma flew hauing flowne perfit round weary wing returnd vnto master judicious arme plact divine wit narrow wombe small flye could finde sufficient roome spring wheeles counterpoise chaines stood insteed life spurre raines desinamus itaque archytae columbam mirari cum muscam cum aquilam geometricis ali alatam noriberga exhibeat saith ramus let v giue ouer wonder archytas doue sithence norinberg hath exhibited fly eagle winged geometricall wing bartas likewise remembers curious diall clock strausburgh selfe haue beheld without admiration would thinke mortall hand could mould new heauens new starres whose whirling course constant winding though contrary wayes marke true monds yeares month dayes yet ti story hath oft beene heard hundred witness auerd neither doth forget exquisite silver spheare matchable archimedes zapores king persia sent present emperour ferdinand solyman great turke mentioned paulus iouius sabellicus carried write twelue men vnframed reframed grand signiours described famianus strada imitation stile vaine lucretius magnesi genus est lapidis mirabile cui si lib prolusione corpus ferri plura stylosve admoveris inde non modo vim motumque trahent quo semper ad vrsam quae lucet vicina polo se vertere tentent verumetiam mira inter se ratione modoque quotquot eum lapidem tetigere stylus simul omnes conspirare situm motumque videbis vnum vt si forte ex altquis romae moveatur alter ad hunc motum quamvis sit dissitus longe arcano se naturai foedere vertat ergo age si quid scire vole qui distat amicum ad quem nulla accedere possit epistola sume planum orbem patulumque notas elementa que prima ordine quo discunt pueri describe per extremas orbis medio que repone jacentem qui tetigit magneta stylum vt versatilis inde litterulam quamcun que velis contingerepossit hujus ad exemplum simili fabricaveris orbem margine descriptum munitum que indice ferri ferri quod motum magnete accepit ab illo hunc orbem dissessurus sibi portet amicus conveniat que prius quo tempore queisve diebus exploret stylus trepidet quidve indice signes ita compositis si clam cupis alloqui amicum quem procul te te terrai distinet os orbi adjunge manum ferrum versatile tracta hic disposta vides elementa margine toto queis opus est ad verba notis hunc dirige ferrum litterulas que modo hano modo illam cuspide tange dum ferrum per ea iterum que iterum que rotando componas singillatim sensa omnia mentis mira fides longe qui distat cernit amicus nullius impulsu trepidare volubile ferrum nunc huc nunc illuc discurrere conscius haeret obseruatque stylus ductum sequiturque legendo hinc que hinc elementa quibus verba coactis quid sit opus sentit ferroque interprete discit quin etiam cum stare stylum videt ipse vicissim si quae respondenda putat simili ratione litterulis varie tactis rescribit amico vtinam haec ratio scribendi prodeat vsu cautior citior properaret epistola nullas latronum verita insidias fluviosque morantes ipse suis princeps manibus conficeret rem no soboles scribarum emersi ex aequore nigro consecraremus calamum magnetis ad ara loade aboue stone hath strange propertie sundry steel thereto needle yee applie force motion thence draw incline turne beare neere pole doth shine nay many steel touch vertuous stone strange wondrous sort conspiring one together moue themselues situate together one steel rome bestird selfesame way stirre though far distant nature force secret sympathie well ought would faine advise friend dwels far letter send large smooth round table make write christcrosse row order verge thereof bestow needle midst toucht load note soere list straight may turne vnto frame another orbe respect like describe edge lay steele thereon likewise steele selfesame magnes motion drew orbe send thy friend time bid adeu dayes agree first meane proue steele stir letter doth moue done thy friend thou closely wouldst advise countrey far distant thee lie take thou orbe steele orbe set christcrosse edge thou seest order writ note frame thy word direct thy steele sometime sometime note wheele turning round often till finde haue compounded meaning minde thy friend dwels far strange doth plainely see steele stir though man stirred bee running heere conscious plot steele guide pursues reades note note gathering word note clearely see whats needefull done needle truchman steele doth cease motion thy friend thinke convenient answere backe send course may take needle write touching seuerall note list indite would god men would pleasd put course vre letter would arriue speedy sure riuers would stoppe theeues intercept prince owne hand businesse might effect wee scribe blacke sea scaped length hearty wils thaltar loade would consecrate quils devise two absent friend might confer great distance circumference certainety conclusion leaue experiment list make tryall conclude comparison touching wit art word bodi non minus peccant method hist cap qui veteribus aiunt omnia comprehensa quam qui illos de veteri multarum artium possessione deturbant habet natura scientiarum thesauros numirabiles qui nullis aetatibus exhauriri possunt lesse blame affirme thing haue found ancient would thrust possession many art found nature science includes infinite treasure neuer exhausted rather lactantius worthy written letter gold lesse true pertinent lib c diuin inst witty elegant dedit omnibus deus pro virili portione sapientiam vt inaudita investigare possent audita perpendere nec quia no illi temporibus antecesserunt sapientia quoque antecesserunt quae si omnibus aequaliter datur occupari ab antecedentibus non potest illibabili est lux claritas solis quia vt sol oculorum sit sapientia est cordis humani quare cum sapere id est veritatem quaerere omnibus sit innatum sapientiam sibi adimunt qui sine vllo judicio inventa maiorum probant ducuntur sed hoc eos fallit quod maiorum nomine posi non patant fieri posse vt aut ipsi plus sapiant quia minores vocantur aut illi de rint quia maiores nominantur god hath giuen wisedome vnto according competent measure might finde thing vnheard weigh thing already ound neither start v time doth likewise follow haue also wisedome indifferently graunted cannot bee forestalled went vnimpaireable like light brightnes sunne light man heart sunne eye sithence wise search truth disposition inbred euery man debarre themselues wisedome without examination approue invention ancestours like vnreasonable creature wholy led others deceiues name ancestours set front thinke cannot either themselues wiser called punies others thing mistaken called ancestours thus haue seene mankind vniversall perpetuall decay regard age life strength stature art wit commonly pretended remaines last place wee examine manner condition vertues vice whether men alwayes grow worse worse likewise generally confidently held beleeved lib iv pretended decay matter manner together large proofe future consummation world testimony gentile v wee draw consideration thereof cap vniversall perpetuall decay manner men pretended first proved generall religion ground manner sect vicissitude revolution vertues vice art science svch neere affinitie mutuall connexion betwixt foure age strength wit manner three former ordinarily follow temper complexion body part doth fourth though must confesse freedome morall matter master fourth three naturall consequently lesse power alter commaund strength comfort age grace strength vertue guide wit age without strength tedious strength without wit dangerous wit without vertue hurtfull pernicious hauing matched men latter age former regard age strength wit likewise proue matchable regard vertue blemish rather ornament discommendation prayse though true vice day abounds thorow world commonly doth well may breed doubt euen best whether last time indeed worst lee dreg age yet consider latter age compare precedent since creation great part knowne world hath beene converted christian doctrine authour hath told v fruites yee shall knowe mee thinkes wrong yeeld world hath thereby beene bettered euen regard civill vertue morall goodnes deus vt parens diligentissimus appropinquante vltimo tempore nuncium misit qui vetus illud seculum fugatamque iusticiam reduceret ne humanum genus maximis perpetuis agitaretur erroribus redijt ergo specie illius aurei temporis saith lactantius god tender father lib c end drawing sent messenger reduce old age banished justice least mankinde alwayes tossed vp downe infinite continuall errours haue brought backe againe vnto v representation golden time cannot easily grant men alwayes place waxe worse worse doe beleiue alwayes place waxe better better stand stay art science likewise matter manner vicissitude alternation revolution hath beene touched part world sometimes better sometimes worse according time warre peace condition prince lawes execution sometimes vertue increaseth one kingdome decreaseth another againe kingdome one vice growes vp another withers leastwise time circulation vertue vice hath beene obserued obseruation thereof commended posterity soundest sagest writer antiquity nisi forte rebus cunctis inest quidam velut orbis quemadmodum temporum vice ita morum vertantur nec omnia apud priores meliora sed nostra quoque aetas multa laudis artium imitanda posteris tulit saith tacitus vnlesse perchance thing certaine circular change turnes annal l c entercourse time also customes manner neither thing ancient time better bur age hath likewise left posterity many thing worthy praise imitation againe vitia erunt donec homines sed neque haec continuum meliorum interventu cerealis apud tacitum hist l pensantur vice long men iast alwayes often recompensed intervening better time accord graue seneca hoc maiores nostri questi sunt hoc no quaerimur hoc posteri nostri querentur euersos esse more de benef l c regnare nequitiam deterius re humanas omne nefas labi ista stant loco eodem stabuntque paululum duntaxat vltra aut citra mota vt fluctus quos aestus accedens longius extulit recedens maiore littorum vestigio tenuit nunc adulterio magi quam alio peccabitur abrumpetque frenos pudicitia nunc conviviorum vigebit furor foedissimum patrimoniorum exitium culina nunc cultus corporum nimius formae cura prae seferens animi deformitatem nunc petulantiam audaciam erumpet male dispensata libertas nunc crudelitatem priuatam ac publicam ibitur bellorum que ciuilium insaniam qua omne sanctum ac sacrum profanetur habebitur aliquando ebrietati honor plurimum meri cepisse virtu erit non expectant vno loco vitia sed mobilia inter se dissentientia tumultuantur invicem fugantur que caeterum idem semper de nobis pronunciare debebimus malos esse no malos fuisse invitus adijciam futuros esse ancestours complained wee complaine posterity complaine manner corrupted wickednes reignes humane affaire grow worse worse stand shall remaine time little remoued sometimes way sometimes way waues tide flowing carry farther ebbing leaues farther sometimes adultery spread selfe sinne immodesty endure bridle sometimes againe madnes feasting fashion kitching basest kinde consuming man patrimony againe immoderate decking body care preseruing beautie much discouers deformitie mind sometimes liberty dispensed breaketh desperate boldnes sometimes cruelty publique private rage civill war whereby holy thing place come profaned time come drunkennes shall honour shall held vertue swill downe much wine vice rest one state place shifting hither thither sighting one another assault put one another flight howeuer goe shall alwayes truly said v wee naught naught wee haue beene vnwillingly adde shall still naught authour hauing related storie asclepiodorus phillippe macedon sent men downe old mine search store man plant tree grown vp cut downe part thereof baketh bread part rosteth meate warmeth himselfe residue thereof maketh god euen idoll carpenter stretcheth line fashioneth red thread planeth pourtraieth compasse maketh figure man according beauty man may remaine house boweth worshippeth prayeth vnto saith deliuer thou art god therevpon inferres haue knowen vnderstood god hath shut eye siluer thing invented art similitude beast vaine stone hath beene made hand antiquity carpenter cutteth downe tree meete worke pareth barke thereof cunningly art maketh vessell profitable vse life thing cut worke bestoweth dresse meat fill himselfe left thing profitable nothing crooked peece wood full knob carueth diligently leisure according hee expert cunning giueth proportion fashioneth similitude man maketh like vile beast straketh ouer vermilion painteth couereth euery spot hath made convenient tabernacle setteth wall maketh fast iron providing lest fall hee knoweth cannot helpe selfe image hath need helpe prayeth good marriage child hee ashamed speake vnto hath life hee calleth weake health prayeth vnto dead life requireth helpe hath experience journey able goe gaine successe affaire asketh ability doe vnable doe thing childish foppery primitiue christian also scoffed laughed quae amentia est aut ea fingere quae ipsi postmodum timeant aut timere quae finxerunt saith lactantius madnesse either make thing themselues feare feare thing themselues haue made nec intelligunt homines ineptissimi quod si sentire simulacrum movere possent vltro adoratura homines fuissent quibus sunt expolita neither doe foolish men vnderstand image adore sense motion would adore framed formed sed haeo nemo considerat ac mentes eorum penitus succum stultitiae perbiberunt adorant ergo insensibilia qui sentiunt irrationalia qui sapiunt exanima qui vivunt terrena qui oriuntur e coelo iuvat ergo velut aliqua sublimi speculum constitutum vnde vniversi exaudire possint generall abolition debt good bad whereby aswell able pay vnable discharged creditor without difference defrauded contrary equity justice cicero saith speaking like case requireth offic lib aboue thing euery man haue owne equall regard rich aswell poore saith way observed cum locupletes suum perdunt debitores lucrentur alienum rich men loose owne debtor gaine belongeth men another solon absurd lawes whosoeuer publique sedition nuter take neither pa remai euer infamous reason hee thought convenient man much loue owne ease participate trouble commonwealth whereof hee member reason together law selfe plutarch wisely worthily rejecteth would assured meanes put fire gunpowder set commonwealth ame without helpe internall remedy saith sicke body hope helpe within selfe expected pa sound therefore body wholly corrupted helpe remedy abroad euen politique body sick sedition internall remedy come whole sound part thereof say neutralls may labour one side compound quarrell otherwise tumult remedy expected except come abroad therefore plutarch holdeth highest principall point politique science governour know either prevent sedition neuer grow else quickly appease growne neuer little least sparke may fall matter may set whole house fire least civill sedition may fall among person time may put whole commonwealth combustion vtterly ruine sect vnreasonable irreligious lawes lycurgus lacedemonian lawgiuer lycurgus wee examine commonwealth lawes thereof shall finde likewise failed true prudence morall vertue whereas good lawmaker ought frame commonwealth lesse religion justice temperance fortitude may stand flourish aswell time peace time warre lawes tended principally make people valiant warlike wherevpon followed lacedemonians flourished long warres came injoy peace fell decay within aristotle noteth whereby pol weaknes lawes lycurgus evidently appeared peace ordained warre warre peace motion labour ordained rest like manner commonwealth rather bee framed ordained peace warre yet may stand commonweaelth lacedemonians way performed lawes lycurgus tending onely make strong laborious valiant could make religious truly temperate ciuill discipline peaceable government requisite lawes tending religion wee finde none made lycurgus religious act one ridiculous religious dedicated image laughter made god least would haue worshipped god make people merry publique feast meeting besides opened great gappe injustice cosenage deceit hee ordained bee lawfull man steale kinde meate taken discouered boyes child haue little allowed eate bee forced sharke proole better provision make thereby industrious nimble quick spirit others wary watchfull keepe well insomuch could steale cunningly commended seeth next way fill commonwealth theeues likely infancy brought vp pilfering trifle afterwards haue got habit ability thereof forbeare steale thing great importance theeues practise occupation safety way become end expert thereby pernicious commonwealth warrant vnder protection law seeing penalty ordained taken manner inflicted injustice fact lacke skill dexterity performance must needes make euery man labour excell act theeuery finally law onely permitteth induceth men deceiue sometimes thing doth also dispose direct deceiue oft howsoeuer may therefore good wise lawmaker seeke prevent euils cut occasion vice minister matter therevnto corrupt nature needeth bridle restraine spurre prick forward may also said respect another law lycurgus inducing intemperancie kinde incontinencie although hee ordained thing notably education youth tending seemed repression concupiscence dissolute life spare homely dyet hard bedding reedes write bedding continuall labour exercise one onely garment iustin l whole yeare like yet appeareth meaning none therein better inable indure labour toyle warre ordayned lawes much fauour furtherance lust carnallity yea worst kind might iustly said made whole commonwealth worse burdell instituted certaine wrestling dance exercise boyes wench naked done publique diuers time yeare presence young old men effect might worke mindes manner citizen man may easily judge especially seeing lawes customes crispus made answer ne musca quidem somuch flie blood fly hee proceeded shedding sue c blood men farre fierce manner vt timeas ne iuvenal satyr vomer deficiat ne marrae sarcula desint well might yee immanitatem potest pro merito describere lib c quae vno loco recubans tamen per totum orbem dentibus ferreis saevit non tantum artus hominum dissipat sed os ipsa comminuit cineres furit ne quis extet sepulturae locus quaenam illa f itas quae rabies quae insania est lucem viuis terram mor uis denegasse man sufficiently describe cruelty vnreasonable beast lying one place yet rageth iron teeth thorow leading army laying waste men dominion razing lib c city sacking townes rooting bringing vnder yoke slauery freeborne people si quis unum hominem jugulaverit pro contaminato nefario habetur nec ad terrenum hoc domicilium deorum admitti eum fa putant ille autem qui infinita hominum millia trucidaverit cruore campos inundaverit flumina infecerit non modo templum sed etiam coelum admittitur apud ennium sic loquitur africanus si f caedendo coelestia scandere cuiquam est mi solo coeli maximum porta patet scilicet quia magnam partem generis humani extinxit ac perdidit quantis tenebris africane versatus e vel potius poeta qui per caedes sanguine patere hominibus asoensum coelum putaveris cui vanitati cicero assensit est vero inquit africane nam herculi eadem ipsa porta patuit tanquam ipse mankinde great darknesse art thou compassed africanus rather thou poet thoughtest slaughter blood entrance opened men heauen yet vanity euen cicero himselfe assent euen africanus saith gate open vnto immortall mine owne part professe would rather die bee death many yet doctrine seemes generally taken deep roote mindes romanes hee shed blood held worthiest holiest man like god fittest hahitation te vt mortem excipias si ita re suadebit cersas epist interest nihil illa ad no veniat ad illam no thou wilt follow counsell prepare thy selfe thou mayst entertaine death nay need thou mayst send matter whether death come v goe death yea mockes derides epist make scruple thereof bono loco re humanae sunt quod nemo nisi vitio suo miser est placet vive si non placet licet eo reverti vnde venisti condition estate happy man miserable default doth thy life please thee liue please thee thou mayst returne thou wilt fro whence thou camest another de iral c place quocun que respexcris ibi malornm see tree whereon others haue beene hanged hang liberty thou wilt hang thy selfe dost thou see thine owne necke throate heart place escape flie bondage hard painefull meanes get wouldest thou yet know condemned wife lepida noble worthy lady divorced husband twenty yeares marriage accused contriuing death poyson long venon likewise king parthia driven owne kingdome betaking himselfe trust people fulgosus reference caligula successour tiberius aswell vice empire threat forced name heire recouered making sueton c sequen ibus wils dispatched poyson holding ridiculous long liue will made bringing money set vp stewes boyes woman palace selfe sent thorow streetes invite men thither increasing emperours revenewes hauing like wretched meanes amassed huge summes treasure satiate appetite contrectandae pecuniae cupidine incensus inflamed longing desire touching money would sometimes walke vpon heapes gold sometimes lay spred abroad large roome rolle himselfe ouer starke naked ingentem nimiamque avaritiam quae tanto imperio tantum principem excaecatum eam vilitatem abjectionem que deduxisti vt neque dedecus suum neque imperii ignominiam agnosceret saith fulgosus transcendent excessiue covetousnes blinded great comander cast extremity basenes become publike pander poysoner loue mony ingenuous minded man though pressed extreame necessity would practise though private monster miracle wonder vespasian reputation perchaunce reason villany good emperour yet euen impotently covetous hee suet onely called arreareages due galbaes time raised new tribute laid vpon province grievous imposition doubling place negotiationes vel privato pudendus propalam exercuit publiquely practised kinde traffick euen private man would shame doe taking vp commodity cheap hand afterward might vent dearer rate neither spare sell honour sued absolution accused whether proued guiltlesse guilty hee thought set purpose haue made choice ravenous poling officer hee could anywhere finde haue advanced highest place thereby growne rich hee might condemne person confiscate good men hee commonly said vse sponge quod quasi siccos madefaceret exprimeret humentes moistned dry wrung qualibet smell gaine good thing whatsoeuer sect whole nation deepely infected vice speake truth whole body people farre possessed dropsie salvianus make nationall lib de prov n disease avaritiae inhumanitas proprium romanorum malum inhumane covetousnesse disease proper romanes accord mithridates iustin non temere se lupi vberibus alitos lib jactare omnet enim habere luporum animos inexplebiles sanguinis imperij divitiarumque avidos esse jejunos without reason boast themselues nourished dugg shee wolfe inasmuch haue insatiable mindes wolues greedily thirsting empire bloud rich well appeared two publique act one peece land controversie betweene ardeatines aricinians joint consent liv dec l referred themselues arbitration romanes binding selues stand award adjudgd themselues senate hauing taken great summes money certaine tributary city make free forced afterward pay old tribute without restoring vnto money paid freedome saith cicero turpe imperio shame empire piratarum enim melior fuit fides quam senatus faith pirats better faith senate dishonest yet know whether followes dishonourable greatest men tooke farme basest tribute mentioned worse yea sued non aliter quam militarem aliquam praefecturam aut civilem magistratum bee word euagrius none otherwise beene great commaund lib c warres principall office city iuvenal speaking small matter raised great fortune thus describes conducunt foricas cur non omnia cum sint iuven sa quales ex humili magna ad fastigia rerum extollit quoties voluit fortuna jocari draught thing else doe hire fortune would merrie highest place doth raise lowest mire marvell seneca complaine haec ipsa re tot magistratus tot judices epist detinet quae magistratus iudices facit pecunia selfesame thing keepes many magistrate iudges place make magistrate iudges wit money mercatores que venales invicem facti quaerimus non quale sit quid sed quanti become merchant hand seeke much quality thing price kinde office thus purchased money place iudicature commonly bought iustice openly sold omnium sermone percrebuit judicijs quae nunc sunt pecuniosum hominem quamvis sit nocens neminem posse damnari saith cicero rife euery man mouth court iustice monied man though bee guilty cannot condemned againe nihil tam sanctum quod non violari nihil tam munitum quod non expugnari pecunia possit nothing sacred money may violated nothing fenced may razed nay catiline could say rome vrbem venalem mature perituram si emptorem invenerit mercenary city soone bee ruined sale might finde chapman without reason haue found word rom radix omnium malorum avaritia covetousnesse roote mischiefe tim taking first letter wordes lye order making vp name without proper signification cap v rome take selfe eagle ensigne iob speaketh dwelleth abideth rock vpon cragge rocke strong place thence seeketh prey eye behold farre young one also suck vp blood slaine generally might verified claudian writes ruffinus plenus sevitiae lucrique cupidine fervens non tartassiacis illum satiaret arenis tempest pretiosa tagi non stagna rubentis aurea pactoli totumque exhauserit hermum ardebit majore siti greedy filthy gaine full cruelty tartessian sand pretious tage golden streames red pactolus satisfie might hermus drink thirst would rage strozza scaurus scaurus habet villa vrbana palatia nummos pinguiaque innumeris praedia bobus arat huic tamen assidue maior succrescit habendi nunquam divitijs exsatiata fame scaurus hath farmes coine city palace many oxe fertile field plowes yet wealth hunger neuer satisfies desire haue still greater growes cap romane luxury matter incontinency drunkennesse sect touch romane luxurie generall particular sin flesh romane covetousnes vnsatiable cruelty vnquenchable luxury incredible recorded owne writer nunc patimur longae pacis mala saevior armis ivven sat luxuria incumbit victumque vlciscitur orbem nullum crimen abest facinus que libidinis ex quo paupertas romana perit suffer plague mischiefes long peace conquerd world revengd luxurie far worse armes since rome poverty cease wanteth attempt crime lecherie pariter que luxuria nata est carthago sublata saith pliny sooner carthage vanquished v luxurie two covetousnesse luxurie mutvally made way luxuriamque lucris emimus luxuque rapinas draw luxurie vnjust gaine man lib rapine luxurie drawne againe eiusmodi tempora constat tacito annalibus esse descripta quibus nulla unquam fuerunt turpissimis vitijs foediora ne que aut virtutum steriliora aut virtutibus inimicitiorae witnesseth causabon preface polybius evident time tacitus described romanorum romane luxurie concluding censure damno damno luxum vestrum romani hac sententia concludo ye romanes damne damne luxury sentence conclude yet certaine hee hath omitted many materiall collection might haue beene added obserueable shall faile make choice vse first excesse sinnes flesh evident acted commonly knowne christian rather desire foulenesse thereof eternally buried oblivion senatours gravest matrones severest magistrate well content grace presence bin commendable profitable exercise florall playes yeare enterludes theater acted vpon open stage almost daily yet abominable godly voute father primitiue christian church hardly write patience specially salvianus whose word purpose smart piercing talia sunt saith quae illic fiunt vt ea non solum dicere sed etiam recordari de gubernat il aliquis sine pollutione non possit alia quippe crimina singulas sibi nobis vendicant portiones vt cogitationes sordidae animum impudici aspectus oculos auditus improbi aures ita vt cum ex vnum aliquid erraverit reliqua possint carere peccatis theatris vero nihil horum reaetu vacat quia concupiscentijs animus auditu aures aspectu oculus polluuntur quae quidem omnia tam flagitiosa sunt vt explicare ea quispiam atque eloqui salvo ore non valeat quis enim integro verecundiae statu dicere queat illas rerum turpium imitationes illas vocum ac verborum obscaenitates illas motuum turpitudines illas gestuum foeditates quae quanti sint criminis vel hinc intelligi potest quod relationem sui interdicunt conclusion quae cum ita sint ecce qualia aut omnes aut pene omnes romani agunt hast thy baker might make thee good bread thou thy selfe mightest long since haue beene made good whereas know content lay fiue hundred pound thee know thee scarce one hundred penny herevnto adde
