patitur humane reason cannot well comprehend nam quingentas ficus passarias quas graeci callistruthias vocant jeiunum comedisse idem cordus dicit centum persica campana melones ostienses decem vuarum lavicarum pondo viginti ficedulas centum ostrea quadraginta morning fasting dispatched fiue hundred dried figges writeth cordus hundred peach campania tenne melones ostia twenty pound weight grape lavica besides hundred bird like nightingall feeding figges gnatgnappers forty oyster dij talem terris avertite pestem god monster v defend phago aurelian tooke singular delight wonderfull eating surpassed mind former ridding one meale emperours presence aprum integrum centum pane vervecem porcellum whole bore hundred loaues weather young pig vopiscus aureliano seeme serving whole bore thing vnvsuall even sate alone private quis feret istas luxuriae sordes quantum est gula quae sibi totos iuven satyr ponit apros animal propter convivia natum filthy luxury endure great beast gut would whole bore ordained feast set satyrist like purpose rancidum aprum antiqui laudabant non quia nasus illis nullus erat sed credo hac mente quod hospes horat l sat tardius adveniens vitiatum commodius quam integrum edax dominus consumeret ancestours well likt rancid boare nose thinke guest came late twas thought much fitter eate tainted one feast founder devour one alone mark anthony saith plutarch twelue guest provided eight boares one set fire another whensoever came sooner latter one least might come prime nay caranus saith athenaeus set every guest boare severall dish haue beene long confesse point infinite vanity extreame madnesse therein hath made rather excesse commonly brought reason generall decrease mankind dayes aswell strength stature age duration though true exceed way much wasting superfluous riotous pampering body would farre better bestowed want necessary yet true farre exceeded v way come short rich dominion yet doubt much hath beene spoken hardly beleeued though haue alleadged owne authous part owne word thereby adde greater weight procure greater credit therevnto nam vetera nunc fere hoc fatum habent vt etsi vera vix videantur sui magnitudine nostra declinatione sayth great antiquarie speaking lypsiius epist select thing ancient record part subject destiny although true yet seeme either thorow owne excesse comming farre short hope shall prepare way easier beleife past follow touching luxurie building appar prodigall expences every way sutable luxurie diet exceeding cap romanes excessiue luxurie building sect excesse great variety farre fetcht deare bought marble chiefest materialls building romanes generally exceeded great variety farre fetcht deere bought marble pliny himselfe eyewitnesse speakes feelingly yet withall wittily best deserues heard though professe make choyce word lie heere sute best present purpose remaines saith write nature stone say principall point enormous abuse height wastfull superfluity thing else haue handled heretofore even booke may seeme sort haue beene made man mountaines nature hath framed selfe partly strengthen certaine ioints within veines bowel earth partly tame violence great river breake force surging waues inundation sea yet notwithstanding wanton pleasure nothing else wee cut hew loade carry away huge hill inaccessible rockes otherwise passe thought wonder ancestours time past reputed miracle manner prodigious first hanniball afterwards cimbrians surmounted alpes even mountaines pierce pickaxe mattocke get thereof hundred sortes marble cleaue cape promontory lay open sea let downe goe head would lay whole world even make levell mighty mountaines set limit bound frontier diverse countreyes seperate one nation another transport carry natiue seate ship build purpose fraught marble cliffes toppes high hill carry fro amid waues billowes sea let every man thinke himselfe excessiue price stone shall heare anon monstrous peeces mass seeth drawne carried land sea let consider withall much faire happy life many man haue without many cannot choose die whensoever goe doe speake truly suffer enterprise also vse else pleasure rather might lie bed chamber stone forsooth spotted never regarded darkenesse night bereaveth one halfe man life delight joyes sect excessiue sumptuousnesse temporary transeunt building made pastime last short time building either private pillar plact yvory roofe guilded beames gract laid ouer either thick guilding plate gold lucanus crassum que trabes absconder aurum thick gold hide beames likewise roofes crasso laquearia fulta metallo thick mettall lind roofes statius best author euerywhere testifie censure quo pertinent haec atrium columnata quo variae istae colorationes quo aurata lacunaria vse entry set rowes pillar diverse colour end roofes guilded word sonius stobaeus roofe capitoll saith pliny guilded till razing carthage quae nunc privatis domibus auro teguntur day euen private men house covered gold nay go farther tels v practise passed roof beames chamber wall qui ipsi jam tanquam vas inaurantur guilded well drinking vessel hierome accord auro paries auro laquearia uro fulgent caput ep ad gaudentium columnarum gold wall gold roofes gold head pillar shine heerein diverse shape artificially exprest appeares statius pretious stone heere glistering among vidi artes veterum que manus varijs que metalla viva modis labor est auri memorare figuras aut ebur aut dignas digitis contingere gemma ancient workes liuing mettals sundry fort see labour twere tell shape gold yvory pretious stone finger fit weare thinke costly gold admirable variety change roofes withdrawing one face exhibiting another pleasure versatilia coenationum laquearia ita coagmentant vt subinde alia facies que alia succedat toties tecta quoties fercula mutentur framd moueable roofes dining roomes senec ep one face succeedes another vary often serue new course seeme rutilius somtime represented groues bird singing quid loqu r inclus inter laquearia sylva vernul qua vario carmine ludit avis pleasant groues within rooofes doe shut bird doe chant vary many note sometimes cast downe flowres abundance buried men vnder fuit tanquam virum tonderet quomodo excandescunt si quid ex juba sua decisum est si quid extra ordinem jacuit nisi omnia annulos suos reciderut quis est istorum qui non malit remp turbati quam comam haires pluckt pincer vpbraided marveile nero exceeded way circa cultum habitum que adeo pudendus shamefull hee suetonius c dressing himselfe alwayes wore haire greeke fashion plaited behind plaitings neither body shame covered woman wearing cannot safely sweare naked yet huge prize fet nation haue traffique woman may expose lesse publique view come abroad doe paramour bed immodesty woman thus also nummos gargiliane sapit foole bought twenty thousand price restore back gargilian wise rich apparelling time wee haue memorable place seneca diligentius quam intra privatum larem vestita de tranq c auro culta mancipia agmen servorum nitentium slaues carefully apparelled decked gold appeare publique within doores troopes servant shining glittering sect prodigall rather prodigious gift emperours extreame vnthriftinesse private men may happily seeme haue beene tedious dwelling long vpon excessiue luxury people surely extreame folly madnesse therein haue made rarity yet variety matter hath beene presume cannot quickly cloy appetite attentiue reader though much hath beene said yet much might added specially touching prodigall rather prodigious gift great patron iustus lypsius thus censure si quis midas fuisse fingatur qui omnia tacta de magn rom faciat aurea defecerit inaurare quantum isti sunt largiti could faine midas turne touched gold surely would weary make gold gaue againe vbi estis qui novum orbem nova eo divitias reperist huc ite ostendent effundent ea duumviri isti vna largitione speake new world great treasure found come hither behold two duumviri meaning anthony octavius empty one gift would know great good purpose profuse largitions author shall tell though somwhat vt ad imperium veniant imperium paene ipsum donant manner giue away empire may come vnto quid donant perdunt certe quomodo tot isti pecuniar cumulus sine aperta pernitie provinciarum civium que colligi potuere said giue away nay rob spoyle empire much great mass treasure could possibly bee gathered without evident ruine well citizen provincial caligula lesse yeare scattered consumed infinite heapes gold silver tiberius predecessour layd vp vicies ac septies millies sestertium suetonius seuen twenty hundred million sesterces vitellius iosephus yeeldes testimony octo menses ac dy quin que potitus imperio debello iudai col jugulatur medium vrbe quam si vivere diutius contigisset ejus luxuriae satis esse imperium non potuisset hauing raigned eight moneths fiue dayes slaine midst city whose luxury haue liued longer empire could haue satisfied lest wee thinke iosephus passionate heerein iew oppressed romanes testimony tacitus himselfe romane partiall countrey wee cannot except let v heare evidence touching vitellius ipse abunde ratus si praesentibus frueretur nec histor longum consultans novies millies sestertium paucissimis mensibus intervertisse creditur holding fully sufficient injoyed th present caring future within compasse moneths said haue set going nine hundred million sesterces summe budoeus casting vp thus pronounces hanc ego summam non minorem lib ducenties vicies quinquies centenis millibus esse dico affirme summe lesse twenty fiue hundred thousand crownes nero divitiarum ac pecuniae fructum non alium putabat quam profusionem thought end money rich cast sueton c away hee held base fellowes tooke account expences gallant noble spirit wasted lavished nothing much commended admired vncle caius short space hee brought going infinite mass treasure tiberius hoarded vp quare nec largiendi nec absumendi modum tenuit neuer ended colunt saturnum quomodo pudicitiam tuebuntur qui colunt deam nudam adulteram quasi apud deos prostitutam quomodo se rapinis fra dibus abstinebunt qui mercurij furta noverunt docentis non fraudis esse decipere sed astutiae quomodo libidine coercebunt qui iovem herculem liberum apollinem caeteros que venerantur quorum adulteria stupra mare faminas non tantum doctis nota sunt sed exprimuntur etiam theatris que cantantur vt sint omnibus notiora possuntne inter haec justi esse homines qui etiamsi natura sint boni ab ipsis tamen dijs erudiantur ad injustitiam ad placandum enim deum quem cola ii cogitation vnto privy intent motion heart christian religion serveth bridle savage wilde cruell man see himselfe able either fraud overreach power overbeare lawes wherevnto subject wherefore great boldnesse offend behooveth men held awe vaine surmise true apprehension man may thinke himselfe able withstand summum praesidium regni est justitia ob apertos tumultus religio ob occultos chiefe ticinum called pavia long tedious journey scarce refreshed wearied army consisting severall nation therefore harder held together commaunded beate scipio consull sent losse almost horse wounded field within fighting consul scipio sempronius trebia escaped six thirty thousand roman tenne thousand sort horse foote long againe encountred flaminius another consull lake thrasymene slaine place amilcar vanquished scipio would say spaine strange little honour beene extreamely dangerous rome vanquished man invade italy indeed incredible narration asdruball closed side knowing escape battell saue steepe descent rock great river lay back ranne away monie elephant broken troupe tagus directly toward pyrenees toward italy vpon hee fell threescore thousand souldiers wherefore wee sorry carthaginian record warres rome vtterly lost wee knowe thereof hath pleased roman tell v vnto wisedome giue much credit albericus gentilis nation italian late professour civilllawes vniversity oxford well versed roman storie hath written two learned bookes de armis romanorum former hee clearely proues roman got reputation great justice wisedome valour testimonie owne writer relation partiall notwithstanding sayth sunt vel ipsis plura disiecta passim quasi amplo naufragio dissipata quae per sedulam operam collecta vincere vulgi opinionem consensum hominum inveteratum superare persuasionem de virtute romanorum bellica tollere possunt even many passage found scattered heere great shipwracke diligently collected put together might serue vanquish vulgar opinion roote inveterate common consent weaken strong perswasion men touching warlike manhood roman alleaging place cicero oration murena virtu militaris populo romano nomen vrbi romae aeternam gloriam peperit military vertue romanes wanne themselues fame citty aeternall glory imo non ita est tulli sayth sed frau avaritia audacia crudelitas illud vobis imperium pepererunt terrae reliquum simpliciorem justiorem humaniorem faciliorem moderationem subegerunt tullie fraud covetousnesse impudence cruelty got empire subdued rest world innocent courteous mercifull moderate peaceable yourselues doth barely affirme substantially make good booke though next seeme haue spoken person another conclude long though trust tedious discourse roman dispute sir walter rawleighs handling probleme proposed discussed livie whether great alexander could haue prevailed roman easterne conquest bent force delivered opinion livy alexander together reason inducing therevnto go preferring english macedonian roman wherein speake reason let heard let bee censured mine owne part must confesse know well answere argument pressing ponderous seeme whether affection haue clouded judgement heerein leaue others judge word sect english inferiour romane valour magnanimity iudgement sir walter rawleigh deciding controversie saith thinkes amisse englishman giue sentence hist world l part cap sect macedonian roman roman chosen arbitrator ardeates aricini stroue peece land saying belonged vnto neither vnto roman themselues therefore demaunded whether macedonian roman best warriour answere englishman soone appeare shall examine noble act nation warre performed advantage weapon savage vnmanly people enemy farre superiour vnto v number needfull provision yea vvell trayned vvee commonly better exercise warre sort philip wanne dominion greece manner men persian indian alexander vanquished likewise force macedonian phalanx well appointed army commonly encountred man hath taken paine read foregoing story doth sufficiently vnderstand yet phalanx neuer seldome able stand roman army embattailed excellent forme know whether nation besides haue vsed either since roman weapon likewise offensiue defensiue greater vse nation hath serued fierie instrument gunpowder knowne enemy rome doe finde ouermatch number farre overmatched weapon shee little advantage armes little advantage multitude also plutarch well obserueth part happinesse shee neuer ouerlaid great warres heereby came passe hauing first increased strength accession sabine hauing wonne state alba adventured owne selfe wager vpon head three champion hauing thereby made selfe princesse latium afterwards long warre many age extend dominion ouer italy carthaginian well nigh oppressed souldiers mercenarie want proper strength easily beaten sumus velut solidissimis carpentur prviledged danger change earth heaven whole frame creature though guided finger god shall alwaies obserue order one day last shall turne course thing haue time borne increase againe die ntinguished thing thou seest wheeling head even vpon seated setled solide shall surprized leaue another place si potest tibi solatio esse commune fatum nihil constat loco stabili nihil qua sint loto stabit omnia sternet abducet que secum vetustas supprimet de consolatione ad martia monte maria sorbebit common destiny thing may whit comfort thee nothing setled stable course nothing shall alwayes remaine state stand time shall carry downe thing shall levell mountaines swallow vp sea lastly naturall question vnus humanum genus lib cap condet dy one day shall burie mankinde yet seeme withall held restoring thing againe omne ex integro animal generabitur dabitur que terris homo inscius scelerum melioribus auspicijs natus cap sed illis quo que innocentia non durabit nisi dum novi sunt cito nequitia subrepet creature shall againe restored mankind shall againe sent inhabite earth kind voyd wickednes borne better fortune yet shall innocencie long endure neither while yet fresh new afterward vngratiousnes degree creepe vpon aelian haue already touched another purpose eight booke historie telleth v mountaine aetna cap thereof might given reason daily wasting consuming affirmes haue beene opinion skilfull secret nature certaine greatest part philosopher aristotle heraclitus empedocles oecumenius collectaneis super post petri anaxagoras democritus others held world beginning time likewise time haue end since aristotle greatest part follower excepted haue ever constantly maintained somuch epicure heerein accord stoickes though opinion differ fire water may appeare lucretius sect epicurean wit much esteemed among ancient principio maria ac terris coelumque tuere de rerum tura hor naturam triplicem tria corpus memmi tres specie tam dissimiles tria talia texta vna dy dabit exitio multos que per annos sustentata ruet mole machina mundi behold memmi first earth sea heaven threefold nature body three three shape farre vnlike three peeces wrought woven fast one day shall bring naught huge frame engine vpheld many yeares length shall fall ovid speaking lucretius seemes haue borrowed part word carmina sublimis tum sunt peritura lucreti eleg exitio brachygraphie writing short markes though practised among roman appeares epigram martiall lib epig currant verba licet manus est velocior illis nondum lingua suum dextra peregit opus another ausonius puer notarum praepetum solers minister advola c epig yet dio referres invention thereof maecaenas manilius seeme time new lib hic scriptor erit foelix cui littera verbum est qui que notis linguam brachygraphie may added writing zifers nota furtivae secret markes hiding writer minde others saue writes farre latter age haue excelled former invention shall appeare wordes hermannus hugo mire sibi gratulabantur veteres insigni seilicet vt ipsi putabant invento epistolarum occulte scribendarum per transpositas literas sed de prim scribendi origi cap profecto id artificium facillime quovis sagaciore deprehendi potest vt non injuria iulius scaliger exercitat id vocet delirium imposturam referam tamen paucula ejus exempla veneratione solius antiquitatis recentiores omnes id genus technas relinquo apud neapolitanum quaerendas lib de notis furtivis quamquam amplissimus consiliarius puteanus epistola quadam ad plouvierium de nonlatin alphabet rationem ostendit occultissimam scribendi per transpositionem quam nec oedipus divinare possit de qua ita nunqaum locuturus fuisset scaliger vt de veterum facili commento iulius caesar inquit dio lib consueverat si quid secreti cuiquam per liter significaret quartum semper elementum soribendo pro eo quod sumi debebat sumere ne obvia literarum lectio cuivis esset augustus autem verba sunt suetonij cap quoties per notam scribit ponit b pro c pro b ac deinceps eadem ratione sequentes litteras pro x autem duplex aa herein doth salmuth fully accord opinion abeant igitur cum sua vetustate tam copiosa frivola veterum commenta longe alios astus longe aliam vafritiem aetas haec videtur exposcere qua vel infantes cum balbutiunt adhuc quaedam subdolae mentis signa veluti primitiae illius ingeruntur quasi nutricis vberibus simul cum lacte illam suxisse imo matris vtero contraxisse videantur neither haue ancient beene excelled modernes wittie invention zifring secret character also testimonie pancirollus dezifring discovering difficult brixianus quidam typis vulgavit modum quendam quem intellecta credit impossibilem nisi quis contra exemplar istius habeat quod tamen falsum est quandoquidem scripturam istam ipsemet explicari audivi quod dici solet quasi cum manu tetigi nullas essenotas adeo difficiles obscuras quae non intelligantur abijs qui hoc scribendi genere exercitati sunt quorum multi venetijs reperiuntur atque ipsemet domi meae habui hieronymum dn francisci nani nobilis veneti filium iuvenem doctissimum artis huius imprimis gnarum cui nullum notarum genus quam difficile etiam id esset fferebatur quin ab ipso intelligeretur pag among late profitable invention mathematiques mirificus logarithmorum canon found lord neper baron merchiston scotland may deservedly challedge place booke intituled dedicates majesty prince epistle dedicatorie giues testimony invention cum nova haec logarithmorum dus omnem illam pristinae matheseos calculo difficultatem penitus e medio ollat ad fublevandam memoriae imbecillitatem se accommodet vt illius adminiculo facile sit plures quaestiones mathematicas vnius spacio quam pristina communiter recepta forma sinuum tangentium secantium vel integro die absolvere testimony may perchance thought partiall touching invention owne therevnto adde graue judgement master igges professour mathematiques oxford hath great diligence much illustrated inlarged praesertim cum deo visum fucrit post epist dedicat car prin evangelij lucem qua orbem hunc nostrum illustrari voluit plurimae humanae vitae vtiliter inventa quorum nullum vti que apud antiquos extiterit vestigium nobis communicare que vt artes mathematicae primarium tenent locum ita illis logarithmorum ratio caeteris partibus precellit sive inventionis spectemus acumen sive vsus praestantiam wherevnto may improperly annexed invention petiscus prefixed word front trigonometrie inventio subtensae tertiae vel quintae vel cujuscunque imparis partis alicujus arcus ex data sola subtensa illius arcus etiam per communem arithmeticam sine omni adminiculo algebrae quae inventio hactenus credita fuit impossibilis invention helpe algebra found long since skilled algebra common arithmetique conclusion pretend answered scaliger againe replied vpon romanus hath best referre determination professours facultie
